label: MCP Reasoning & Planning Repos
behavioralSignal: Builder chose to work on reasoning/auditability within MCP ecosystem
thoughtboxRelevance: MCP + reasoning/planning = direct integration path for Thoughtbox
rationale: Developers building MCP servers that specifically address reasoning, planning, or decision logging are the highest-fit audience. They already understand the protocol AND are solving the same problem Thoughtbox solves.

query.query: MCP server repositories implementing agent reasoning, thought tracking, planning, or decision logging

criteria.description: Repository implements the Model Context Protocol and includes features for reasoning, planning, memory, or thought chain management
Repository has meaningful original code, not just a fork or template with no changes
Repository README or documentation mentions structured reasoning, agent planning, or decision auditability

enrichments.description: Extract the repository owner's GitHub username, email if available in profile, and any linked personal website or blog
Describe how the repository handles agent reasoning or planning and whether it logs or tracks agent decisions

beforeAfter.before: Q1 queried all MCP server implementations broadly (100 results). No behavioral filter for reasoning interest.
beforeAfter.after: NQ1 filters to MCP repos that specifically address reasoning, planning, or decision auditability (75 results). Behavioral signal: builder chose to work on reasoning within MCP.

label: Agent Orchestration Tool Companies
behavioralSignal: Company has written about agent coordination pain in their blog, docs, or product page
thoughtboxRelevance: Companies building agent orchestration tools are natural partners or integration targets
rationale: Merges 'AI Agent Framework Companies' and 'Developer Tool Companies with AI Integration' into a single query targeting companies that have publicly discussed agent coordination or debugging challenges. The behavioral criterion (blog/docs discuss coordination pain) filters for companies that already understand the problem.

query.query: companies building AI agent orchestration, agent debugging, or multi-agent coordination tools

criteria.description: Company builds tools or platforms for orchestrating, debugging, or monitoring AI agents
Company blog, documentation, or product page discusses challenges of agent coordination, agent observability, or debugging agent behavior
Company has a publicly available product, open source project, or documented API

enrichments.description: Extract the company's website URL, contact email, and names of founding team members or CTO
Describe what agent coordination or debugging challenges the company addresses in their product or blog content

beforeAfter.before: Q2 (50) targeted 'startups building AI agent frameworks'. Q7 (50) targeted 'companies building developer tools with AI features'. Combined 100 results, overlapping, demographic-level criteria.
beforeAfter.after: NQ2 (50) merges both into companies specifically building agent orchestration/debugging tools whose public content discusses coordination challenges. Behavioral signal: written about the pain.

label: Agent Opacity Pain Tweets
behavioralSignal: Person publicly expressed frustration with not understanding what their AI agent did or why
thoughtboxRelevance: Direct expression of the exact pain Thoughtbox's auditability feature solves
rationale: Shifted from 'Claude Code power users' (tool choice signal) to tweets expressing the specific pain of agent opacity. Finding people who have complained about not knowing what their agent did is the highest-intent signal possible.

query.query: developers frustrated with AI agent behavior, debugging what AI agents did, wanting to see agent reasoning or trace agent actions

criteria.description: Tweet expresses frustration, difficulty, or curiosity about understanding what an AI agent did or why it made specific decisions
Tweet author has a GitHub profile link or lists a technical role (engineer, developer, CTO, founder) in their Twitter bio
Tweet discusses a specific debugging scenario or agent behavior issue, not just generic AI commentary

enrichments.description: Extract the tweet author's Twitter handle, display name, bio description, and any linked GitHub profile or website
Describe the specific agent opacity problem the author encountered or discussed in the tweet

beforeAfter.before: Q3 targeted 'Claude Code workflow tips and experiences' (50 results). Signal was tool choice, not pain expression.
beforeAfter.after: NQ3 targets tweets expressing frustration with agent opacity (50 results). Behavioral signal: person expressed the exact pain Thoughtbox solves.

label: Agent Observability & Tracing Repos
behavioralSignal: Builder has invested effort in solving agent observability — already knows the pain
thoughtboxRelevance: Agent observability tools are complementary to or competing with Thoughtbox's reasoning ledger
rationale: Shifted from 'multi-agent systems' (category) to 'agent observability and tracing tools' (pain response). Developers who build tools to make agent behavior visible have already identified and invested in solving the same problem Thoughtbox addresses.

query.query: repositories for AI agent observability, agent trace logging, LLM call tracing, or agent behavior debugging tools

criteria.description: Repository provides tools for tracing, logging, or visualizing AI agent actions and decisions
Repository README or documentation describes the problem of understanding agent behavior or auditing agent reasoning
Repository has original implementation code, not just a wrapper or fork

enrichments.description: Extract the repository owner's GitHub username, email if available in profile, and any linked personal website or blog
Describe how the repository approaches agent observability and what visibility it provides into agent reasoning or behavior

beforeAfter.before: Q4 targeted 'multi-agent AI systems with coordination' (50 results). Category-level query, no observability focus.
beforeAfter.after: NQ4 targets repos specifically building agent observability, tracing, and debugging tools (50 results). Behavioral signal: builder invested in making agent behavior visible.

label: OSS Maintainers Using AI Agent Workflows
behavioralSignal: OSS maintainer has publicly written about using AI agents in maintenance workflows
thoughtboxRelevance: OSS maintainers with agent workflow experience are technically sophisticated and already coordinating with AI agents
rationale: Tightened from 'open source maintainers using AI tools' to maintainers who have specifically written about AI agent workflows for code review, triage, or PR analysis. The public writing criterion (reviewer feedback) ensures the behavioral signal is web-observable.

query.query: open source maintainers who have written about using AI agents for code review, automated triage, or PR analysis workflows

criteria.description: Person maintains a publicly known open source project in developer tools, infrastructure, or AI
Person has written publicly (blog posts, tweets, conference talks, or GitHub discussions) about using AI agents in their maintenance workflow
Person discusses challenges of managing or debugging AI-assisted development workflows

enrichments.description: Extract the person's email address, Twitter/X handle, GitHub username, and personal website or blog
Describe what AI agent workflows the person uses in their maintenance work and what challenges they have discussed

beforeAfter.before: Q9 targeted 'open source maintainers using AI assistants' (50 results). Demographic-level, criteria used star counts (not web-observable).
beforeAfter.after: NQ5 targets maintainers who have publicly WRITTEN about AI agent workflows (50 results). Behavioral signal: demonstrated experience + public writing about agent challenges.

label: Agent Orchestration Educators
behavioralSignal: Educator specifically teaches multi-agent systems, agent orchestration, or agent debugging
thoughtboxRelevance: Educators teaching agent coordination understand the pain deeply AND amplify to their audience (multiplier effect)
rationale: Tightened from 'technical educators teaching AI development' to educators specifically teaching agent orchestration and debugging. These people both understand the pain and serve as distribution channels to their audiences.

query.query: technical educators and content creators teaching AI agent orchestration, multi-agent systems, or agent debugging techniques

criteria.description: Person creates educational content (blog, YouTube, course, newsletter) specifically about building or debugging AI agent systems
Person has published content about multi-agent coordination, agent reasoning, or agent observability challenges
Person demonstrates technical depth by showing code examples, architecture diagrams, or hands-on tutorials

enrichments.description: Extract the person's email address, Twitter/X handle, YouTube channel URL, newsletter URL, and personal website
Describe what agent orchestration or debugging topics the person teaches and what platforms they use to reach their audience

beforeAfter.before: Q11 targeted 'technical educators teaching AI development and prompt engineering' (50 results). Too broad, no agent-specific focus.
beforeAfter.after: NQ6 targets educators specifically teaching agent orchestration, multi-agent systems, and debugging (50 results). Behavioral signal: teaches the exact domain + technical depth criterion.

label: Agent Orchestration Engineers
behavioralSignal: Engineer has published about or built agent orchestration systems — not just a job title
thoughtboxRelevance: Engineers actively building agent orchestration are direct users for Thoughtbox's multi-agent Hub
rationale: Merges 'AI Consultants & ML Freelancers' and 'AI/ML Engineers & Prompt Engineers' into a single query with behavioral criteria. The key improvement: criterion 3 requires published technical content (blog posts, talks, open source), which addresses the reviewer's concern about pure job-title targeting.

query.query: engineers and technical leads building AI agent orchestration systems, multi-agent platforms, or agent debugging infrastructure

criteria.description: Profile describes hands-on work building, deploying, or managing AI agent systems or multi-agent platforms
Profile shows experience with agent orchestration frameworks, LLM pipeline tooling, or agent observability tools
Person has published technical content (blog posts, conference talks, open source contributions) about agent systems or reasoning tooling

enrichments.description: Extract the person's name, LinkedIn URL, current company, role title, personal website, and email if available
Describe what agent orchestration or reasoning tooling work the person has done and whether they build infrastructure or use existing tools

beforeAfter.before: Q12 (50) targeted AI consultants by LinkedIn title. Q13 (100) targeted AI/ML engineers by LinkedIn title. Combined 150 results, pure demographic targeting.
beforeAfter.after: NQ7 (75) merges both into engineers building agent orchestration, with behavioral criterion requiring published technical content. Signal: demonstrated expertise, not just title.

label: Agent Debugging Blog Authors
behavioralSignal: Person has written in depth about the exact problem Thoughtbox addresses — agent debugging and reasoning transparency
thoughtboxRelevance: Thought leaders who write about agent debugging are pre-qualified for Thoughtbox's value proposition
rationale: New query targeting the purest behavioral signal: people who have published blog posts specifically about AI agent debugging, reasoning transparency, or behavior auditability. These are thought leaders in the exact problem space.

query.query: developers and engineers who have written blog posts about AI agent debugging, agent reasoning transparency, or auditing AI agent behavior

criteria.description: Person has published a blog post or technical writeup specifically about debugging AI agent behavior or making agent reasoning visible
The writing describes practical experience with multi-agent systems, agent orchestration, or LLM-powered workflows
Person demonstrates technical depth through code snippets, architecture discussion, or tool recommendations

enrichments.description: Extract the person's name, email address, Twitter/X handle, blog URL, and GitHub username
Summarize what agent debugging or reasoning transparency approaches the person advocates and what tools they currently use or recommend

beforeAfter.before: No R2 equivalent. This signal was not captured.
beforeAfter.after: NQ8 finds thought leaders who have written about agent debugging and reasoning transparency (50 results). Purest behavioral signal in the set.

label: Claude Multi-Agent Workflow Tweets
behavioralSignal: Person is actively building multi-agent Claude Code workflows — immediate Thoughtbox user
thoughtboxRelevance: Claude Code multi-agent workflows are the primary use case for Thoughtbox's Hub feature
rationale: New query targeting developers who are already using multiple Claude Code agents or MCP servers in coordinated workflows. These people are the most immediate potential Thoughtbox users because they are already doing multi-agent coordination with the same tool ecosystem.

query.query: developers sharing multi-agent Claude Code workflows, agent team coordination with Claude, or MCP server orchestration setups

criteria.description: Tweet describes using multiple AI agents or Claude Code instances working together on a project
Tweet author has a GitHub profile link or lists a technical role in their Twitter bio
Tweet describes a specific multi-agent workflow, coordination pattern, or discusses agent team management challenges

enrichments.description: Extract the tweet author's Twitter handle, display name, bio description, and any linked GitHub profile or website
Describe the multi-agent workflow or coordination pattern the author uses with Claude Code or other AI agents

beforeAfter.before: No R2 equivalent targeting multi-agent Claude workflows specifically.
beforeAfter.after: NQ9 finds developers actively building multi-agent Claude Code workflows (50 results). Behavioral signal: already doing multi-agent coordination with Claude.

label: Multi-Agent Coordination Framework Repos
behavioralSignal: Builder invested in multi-agent coordination — Thoughtbox Hub directly addresses their coordination needs
thoughtboxRelevance: Multi-agent framework builders need exactly the coordination primitives Thoughtbox Hub provides (workspaces, problems, proposals, consensus)
rationale: Refocused from the broad R2-Q4 multi-agent systems query to specifically target repos that implement agent communication, task delegation, or shared state patterns. The criterion requiring docs that discuss coordination challenges ensures behavioral signal.

query.query: repositories implementing multi-agent LLM frameworks with agent communication, task delegation, or shared memory between agents

criteria.description: Repository implements a framework where multiple AI agents communicate, delegate tasks, or share state
Repository documentation describes challenges or solutions for agent coordination, conflict resolution, or consensus
Repository is actively maintained (updated within last 12 months) with meaningful code

enrichments.description: Extract the repository owner's GitHub username, email if available, and any linked personal website or blog
Describe the multi-agent coordination architecture used and what communication patterns the agents employ

beforeAfter.before: Q4 broadly targeted 'multi-agent AI systems with coordination and collaboration' (50 results). Category-level, no coordination-challenge focus.
beforeAfter.after: NQ10 targets repos specifically implementing agent communication, delegation, and shared state with docs discussing coordination challenges (50 results). Behavioral signal: builder invested in coordination problem.
